abstract.p: Bronx Institute of Lehman College research director David Badillo letter responds to June 10 article about new immigrants and Latino religion

block.p: I am writing with considerable concern and disappointment with regard to your June 10 article ''The Hallelujah People.'' When your reporter interviewed me over the phone, I discussed Latino religion and the circumstances of new immigrants generally. With regard to the group Growing in Grace, about which I clearly admitted very little familiarity, I concluded that its significance within the larger picture of Latino religiosity was minimal, at best.

I am writing with considerable concern and disappointment with regard to your June 10 article ''The Hallelujah People.'' When your reporter interviewed me over the phone, I discussed Latino religion and the circumstances of new immigrants generally. With regard to the group Growing in Grace, about which I clearly admitted very little familiarity, I concluded that its significance within the larger picture of Latino religiosity was minimal, at best.

Had you reported this -- and put my quotes on recent immigrants and their needs and contributions in context -- there would have been much less substance to the story. As is, it appeared that this group represented some kind of an emerging mainstream religious trend among Latinos.

It seems to me essential that such an examination at least acknowledge the very strong ongoing Latino support for Catholicism -- with all of its shortcomings -- as well as the tremendous impact of countless well-established Protestant denominations.
David A. Badillo Bedford Park, the Bronx
The writer is research director at the Bronx Institute of Lehman College and author of ''Latinos and the New Immigrant Church.''
